stations.title: ğŸ”¬ Learning Stations
stations.content: Explore 6 interactive stations covering color formats, systems, harmony, accessibility, modern CSS, and AI assistance. HAP guides you through hands-on examples!

hex-shorthand.title: ğŸ¨ Hex Shorthand Mystery Solved!
hex-shorthand.content: I was so confused when I saw #369 and #336699 in the same file! Prof. Teeters explained that #RGB is shorthand for #RRGGBB. Each digit doubles: #369 = #336699, #fff = #ffffff. Mind blown! ğŸ¤¯

hsl-advantage.title: ğŸ¯ Why HSL Changed Everything
hsl-advantage.content: Prof. Teeters said "HSL is like having a color remote control" and she was SO right! Want a darker version? Keep H and S, just lower L! With hex codes, I was guessing. With HSL, it's math. hsl(210, 50%, 50%) â†’ hsl(210, 50%, 40%) for darker. Easy!

rgb-screens.title: ğŸ“º How Screens Actually Work
rgb-screens.content: RGB made no sense until Prof. Teeters explained it's based on how screens work - mixing red, green, and blue light. Each value (0-255) is how bright that color channel is. rgb(255, 0, 0) = full red, no green, no blue = pure red! It's literally controlling tiny lights in your screen!

semantic-naming.title: ğŸ·ï¸ Semantic Naming Saves Lives
semantic-naming.content: I used to name colors --blue, --green, --red. Then the client changed from blue to orange. Prof. Teeters taught me semantic naming: --primary, --success, --error. Now when colors change, I only update ONE place. Game changer!

60-30-10.title: ğŸ¡ The 60-30-10 Rule
60-30-10.content: Prof. Teeters taught me the professional designer secret: 60% dominant color, 30% secondary, 10% accent. My old sites had equal amounts of every color - total chaos! Now I use 60% neutrals (background), 30% brand color, 10% accent. It just looks right!

gray-scales.title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Creating Perfect Gray Scales
gray-scales.content: Creating a gray scale with hex? Nightmare. With HSL? Keep hue and saturation at 0, just change lightness! --gray-100: hsl(0, 0%, 95%) down to --gray-900: hsl(0, 0%, 10%). Ten seconds, done. Prof. Teeters was right: HSL is the systematic approach!

color-wheel.title: ğŸ¨ The Color Wheel as Degrees
color-wheel.content: Prof. Teeters blew my mind: HSL hue IS the color wheel as numbers! 0Â° = red, 120Â° = green, 240Â° = blue, 360Â° = back to red. Want the opposite color? Add 180Â°! If primary is hsl(210, 60%, 50%), complement is hsl(30, 60%, 50%). Math beats guessing!

complementary.title: ğŸ¯ Complementary = Add 180Â°
complementary.content: I used to pick "opposite" colors randomly. Prof. Teeters showed me: complementary colors are exactly 180Â° apart on the color wheel. Blue at 210Â°? Complement is 210 + 180 = 30Â° (orange). Works every time. No color picker needed!

analogous.title: ğŸŒˆ Analogous = Neighbors
analogous.content: Analogous colors sit next to each other on the color wheel - usually 30Â° apart. Prof. Teeters taught me: if primary is 210Â° (blue), analogous colors are 180Â° (teal) and 240Â° (blue-purple). They always harmonize because they share the same color family. So easy with HSL!

wcag-aa.title: â™¿ WCAG 2.2 Level AA Explained
wcag-aa.content: Prof. Teeters taught me: WCAG 2.2 Level AA requires 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text (14-18px), and 3:1 for large text (18px+ or 14px+ bold). This isn't optional - it's the law in many places! Test EVERY color combination. WebAIM's contrast checker is my best friend now.

contrast-ratio.title: ğŸ”¬ Understanding Contrast Ratios
contrast-ratio.content: I thought contrast was just "dark vs light." Prof. Teeters explained it's relative luminance math. 4.5:1 means the lighter color is 4.5Ã— more luminous. Pure white on pure black? 21:1 (maximum). Pale gray on white? Maybe 1.5:1 (fails). Green needs to be much darker than blue to pass - luminance matters!

cvd-testing.title: ğŸ‘ï¸ Color-Vision Deficiency Testing
cvd-testing.content: 8% of men and 0.5% of women have color-vision deficiency (CVD). Prof. Teeters showed me Chrome DevTools can simulate CVD! DevTools â†’ Rendering â†’ Emulate vision deficiencies. Never use color alone - pair with icons, labels, or patterns. Red/green issues? Test it!

gradients.title: ğŸ¨ CSS Gradients vs Images
gradients.content: I used to export gradient images from Photoshop - 20KB each! Prof. Teeters showed me: background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--primary), var(--secondary)); - that's it! Zero KB, infinite variations, scales perfectly. Plus I can adjust colors in CSS instead of re-exporting images. Why didn't anyone tell me sooner?!

color-mix.title: ğŸ”¬ color-mix() is Magic
color-mix.content: I used to guess hover colors - #3366cc â†’ #4477dd? Close enough? Prof. Teeters introduced me to color-mix(): color-mix(in srgb, var(--primary) 80%, white) = mathematically perfect 20% lighter. No guessing, no color picker, just math. Works in all modern browsers!

dark-mode.title: ğŸŒ Automatic Dark Mode
dark-mode.content: I thought dark mode needed duplicate CSS files. Prof. Teeters showed me @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) - one media query, flip a few colors, done! OS detects user preference automatically. Just flip background, text, and borders. Accent colors often stay the same. Ship dark mode in 10 minutes!

vibe-coding.title: ğŸ¤– Why Vibe Coding Fails
vibe-coding.content: Prof. Teeters calls it "vibe coding" - throwing prompts at AI and hoping for the best. I used to say "make it pretty" *paste*. She taught me: YOU are the director. AI suggests, YOU decide. Use AI to accelerate what you understand, not skip understanding. Be the human in the loop!

drift.title: âš ï¸ AI Drift is Annoying But Normal
drift.content: Prof. Teeters warned me about "drift" - AI loses context and reverts to bad habits. I start with perfect --primary: hsl(210, 50%, 50%), three prompts later AI is back to hex codes and calling them "variables"! When you spot drift, remind the AI: "Remember: HSL custom properties only." Annoying but normal!

terminology.title: ğŸ“š CSS Custom Properties NOT Variables
terminology.content: AI was trained on millions of tutorials that incorrectly say "CSS variables." Prof. Teeters taught me to always correct it! The spec calls them "CSS custom properties". When AI says "Here are your CSS variables," I respond: "Use the term 'CSS custom properties' with --property-name syntax." Precision in language = precision in code!

verify.title: ğŸ” Trust But Verify AI Claims
verify.content: AI told me my pale yellow on white was "perfectly accessible." Prof. Teeters had me check - 1.9:1 ratio, massive fail! She taught me: AI is great for suggestions but can misstate contrast math. Now I use AI to generate HSL palettes, then manually verify EVERY contrast ratio with WebAIM. Trust, but verify!

prompt-formula.title: ğŸ¯ The Magic Prompt Formula
prompt-formula.content: Prof. Teeters taught me: Context + Mood + Constraints. BAD: "nice colors" GOOD: "E-commerce site for outdoor gear, earthy and trustworthy, need success/error states, must meet WCAG 2.2 Level AA, output as HSL custom properties with semantic names." Specific prompts get professional results!
